content.webTitle: Film preview:  International Buddhist Film Festival, London

fields.headline: Film preview:  International Buddhist Film Festival, London
fields.bodyText: Most of us won't be running off to a Himalayan monastery any time soon, but we can get a rather more digestible slice of Buddhism to go with this cinematic tribute to all that's enlightened, compassionate and zen. It's an eclectic mix of the dreamlike and the didactic, including rare 1925 silent Prem Sanyas, on the life of the Buddha himself (pictured), with live sitar and tabla accompaniment, Hometown Of The Heart, one of only two Korean films to have survived the war, and The Devotion Of Matthieu Ricard, a charming documentary about a monk described as "the happiest man alive". Also screening are rather more familiar films on a Buddhist tip, like Donnie Darko and Dead Man, which epitomise the concept of the bardo, the gap between one life and the next; a genre-defying genre if ever there was one.
